title: Long maximum
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x, y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be real numbers satisfying "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y = 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". To 2 decimal places, what is the maximum value of "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^4 y + x^3 y + x^2 y + x y + x y^2 + x y^3 + x y^4 ? "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Other problems: "},{"type":"text","text":"Check your Calibre","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} z & = x^4y + x^3y+x^2y+xy+xy^2+xy^3+xy^4 \\ & = xy \left(x^3+x^2+x+1+y+y^2+y^3 \right) \\ & = xy \left({\color{#3D99F6} x^3 + y^3}+{\color{#D61F06}x^2+y^2}+x+y+1 \right) & \small \color{#3D99F6} \text{See notes.} \\ & = xy \left({\color{#3D99F6}27-9xy}+{\color{#D61F06}9-2xy}+3+1 \right)  \\ & = xy \left(40-11xy \right) \\ & = - 11 \left((xy)^2 - \frac {40}{11}xy \right) \\ & = \frac {20^2}{11} - 11 \color{#3D99F6} \left(xy - \frac {20}{11} \right)^2  \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#3D99F6} \left(xy - \frac {20}{11} \right)^2 \ge 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is maximum when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#3D99F6} \left(xy - \frac {20}{11} \right)^2 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z_{max} = M = \dfrac {400}{11}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies \lfloor M \rfloor = \lfloor 36.\dot 3 \dot 6 \rfloor = \boxed{36}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Notes:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\small \begin{aligned} x^2+y^2 & = (x+y)^2 - 2xy = 9 - 2xy \\ x^3+y^3 & = (x+y)(x^2+y^2 - xy) = 27 - 9xy \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By taking xy=t and the taking xy common from the expression."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"we get expression Value as : t(40-11t) . Since  we know that x+y=3 . "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So maximum value of xy=2.25."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"But you may get doubt that both need not be positive but they have to be positive because if one of x,y is negative then other one will be positive making their product negative by which the expression will be negative so both should be positive so I applied A.M.â‰¥G.M.."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For the expression t(40-11t) to be maximum t=40/22.so t<2 . "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which is possible so therefore maximum is at t=40/22. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So ,(40/22)(40-11(40/22))=800/22=36.36.. so answer is 36.36 .ðŸ˜Ž"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 10 Nearsighted People
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" nearsighted people all put their glasses in a bin. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Andy, Brandy, Candy, and Dandy all have the same prescription. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Endy, Fandy, and Grandy have the same prescription, which is different from the other seven people. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Handy and Indy have the same prescription (again, which is different from the rest of the people). "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Jandy's prescription is unique."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If the probability after they all randomly choose a pair from the bin that they can all see clearly (long distance) is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{b}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", what is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number of ways they can pick the glasses is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number of ways they can all choose glasses with the right prescription is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4! \cdot 3! \cdot 2! \cdot 1!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, the probability is:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P = \frac{4! \cdot 3! \cdot 2! \cdot 1!}{10!} = \frac{1}{\boxed{12600}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 10n10^n10n Game
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There is a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that cannot be factorized into two numbers which does not contain any zero, for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n>0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Find the smallest "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that satisfies the statement above. If there isn't any put "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as answer."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^n = 2^n\times 5^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus, when factored, the two factors will both be of the form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^a5^b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a>0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b>0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^a5^b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" will be divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and thus contain a zero. So we only need to consider factorizations of the form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^n = (2^n) \times (5^n)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{array}{c|c|c}
n & 2^n & 5^n \\ \hline
1 & 2 & 5 \\
2 & 4 & 25 \\
3 & 8 & 125 \\
4 & 16 & 625 \\
5 & 32 & 3125 \\
6 & 64 & 15625 \\
7 & 128 & 78125 \\
8 & 256  & 390625
\end{array}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=\boxed{8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the smallest "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for which every factorization of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" contains a number with a 0."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I misread the problem to mean both numbers don't contain zero.  In other words in any factorization both numbers contain zero.  In this case the answer is n=12.  Since both 2^12 and 5^12 contain a zero.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 10^N Less Than N^10
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many positive integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are there such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 10^n \\leq n^{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"? "}]}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            So what's the correct justification and solution to this?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Only 2 correct solutions were submitted, of which this is one of them. Students had major difficulties justifying their opinions, and even wrote contradictory statements. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The most common argument was that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^n "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 'obviously' grows faster than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n^{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If this statement is true, it would contradict the fact that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not a solution but "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a solution, which they were all too happy to mention in the next paragraph. Students who even tried to justify this "by differentiating" clearly didn't do the differentiation, or did it wrong (as in several cases). The statement that "Exponential growth is faster than Polynomial growth" is only true for sufficiently large "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and not necessarily true for small values. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Another common mistake made was in not understanding the graph "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac {n}{\log n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" completely, and attempting to calculate when this is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":">10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  It can be difficult to justify that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac {n}{\log n} = 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" only has 2 roots, unless you really understand the behavior of this graph.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For n>10 LHS>RHS
We can use induction to prove it.
For n=1 we have 10>1
For 2=<n=<10 the inequality is true"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Due to the fact that the logarithm function is strictly increasing then we can change the inequality to"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \le 10\, \log_{10}n."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Those two functions take the same value for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=\{1.37....,10\}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Although one can not know immediately the first solution at least one can deduce it is between 1 and 2."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solutions need to be between 2 and 10, because values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" greater than 10 do not satisfy the proposed condition."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the final answer is 9, corresponding to the positive integers between 2 and 10, both included."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Transform the inequality by taking the log base 10 of both sides to see
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \leq 10 \log n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". We can do this because log is defined on all positives, is one-to-one, and is increasing. Note, we have equality when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is 10. Furthermore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" grows faster than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\log n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so 10 must be the largest "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for which the inequality holds. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We just need to check for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" less than 10, and we readily see that only when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is 1, does the inequality not hold. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the solution set is all positive integers less than or equal to 10 except. Then counting on our fingers we see that there are 9 such integers. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"step 1: check for 1: 10^1 ? 1^10  ---->   10 >1  so, 1 doesn't belong to the answer.
step 2: check by putting n=2, we find that 10^2<2^{10}. obviously, all n<10 belong to the set of our answer.
step 3: now, 10^{10}=10^{10}. so, 10 also belongs to the answer. (if you want, you can check by putting n>10 ----> n=11)
step 4: neglecting 1, we find this pattern:  10^(n<10) < (n<10)^{10}  ,  10^(n=10) = (n=10)^{10}  ,  10^(n>10) > (n>10)^{10}
step 5: count the number of elements of the set of answers, i.e., 2,,3,4.......10 which is equal to 10-1=9
step 6: the answer is 9."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For n=1, (10^1)/(1^10)=10/1=10>1, not valid
For n=10, 10^10=10^10, equality valid
Now, for n=2, (10^2)/(2^10)=(5^2)/(2^8) is proper fraction<1,valid
Likely for n=3,4,5,6,7,8,9 it is correct.
Now, for n=11, (10^11)/(11^10)=10(10^10)/(11^10) is improper fraction>1, not valid
Just like, n=12,13 or more the given relation becomes invalid.
Therefore, number of positive integers is 9."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"to solve this problem, simple:
1. When we substitute n integer=1, the result will be 10<=1 and surely that's not fulfill the condition of "<=".
2. Start from n=2 until n=9, the result will fulfill the requirement of "<
" than ....
3. Next we get n=10, where the result will be equally same 10^10 = 10^10 and still fulfill the requirement of "="
4.Start from n=11 until n= inf the result has not fulfilled the requirement which ">" than ...
So the array of n's integer is = {2,3,4,...,10) which the length is 9."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Taking natural logarithm on both sides, we have:
lg 10^n <= lg n^10
n<= 10 lg n
n/(lg n) <= 10 
Since if n =10, n/(lg n) = 10, then n <= 10.
But n = 1 would mean lg n = 0, rendering n/(lg n) undefined, hence there are only 9 possible positive integer values for n (2 to 10 inclusive)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The first important thing to note is that the smallest such value for n is 2, since 10^1>1^10. Next, note that since the equation asks for a value greater than OR EQUAL to 10^n. So, it is easy to see both sides ate equal when n=10, since both sides are 10^10. Finally, we note that  10^n increases significantly faster than n^10. This can be shown by taking their derivatives:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(d/dn)10^n at n=10 is ln10"},{"type":"text","text":"10^10.
(d/dn)n^10 at n=10 is 10","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"10^9= 10^10."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since ln10>1, 10^n>n^10 if n>10. So, the solutions are the integers 2-10 inclusive, which consist of 9 numbers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=1 is obviously not possible
Case of n=2, 10^2 < 2^10 
Case of n=10, 10^10 = 10^10
that means it holds for 2â‰¤nâ‰¤10 until now.
Case of n=11
10^11= (10^5 x 10^(1/2))^2 
Since the square root of 10 is 3.16227766..., we got
10^11 > 300000^2 > 161051^2 = (11^5)^2 = 11^10, 
n=11 is false,
for n > 11,
the LHS will be multiplied by 10 and the RHS will be multiplied by k^10 (where k = (n+1)/n for n >11) and since the k is indirectly propotional to n, the max value of k is 1.1^10 = 2. ... < 10, for n >11 , the inequality will always fail. QED"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can check that the integers 2 to 10 satisfy the condition. For "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n \geq 11"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we will show by induction that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^n > n^{10} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Going from "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we are multiplying the LHS by 10, and multiplying the RHS by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \left(\frac {k+1}{k}\right)^{10} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is less than or equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \left(\frac {11}{10} \right)^{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is less than 10. (For example, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1.1^5 = 1.61051 < 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", implying "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1.1^{10} < 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence, there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10-2+1 = 9 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such positive integers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1^10 = 1, which means 10^1 < 1 is false.
On the other hand, if you calculate 10^2 and 2^10 (100 and 1024) you will see that this is right.
Same for 3,4,5,...,8,9 and 10! 
10^10 = 10^10 so this is right too!
Then 10^11 is obviously bigger than 11^10 => The soultions are following: {2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9,10} //that's nine numbers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since we know that 10^10 = 10^10, the maximum value of n must be 10. Also, we know that n cannot be 1 because 1 is not greater that 10. Hence the smallest possible value of n will be 2, because 1024 is more that 100."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus, n can be any number from 2 to 10, or 10-2 + 1 = 9 numbers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 10 oh 10
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The ten's digit of the following number is (23^41)*(25^40)"}]}]}

title: 10 or 100
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the sum of all digits of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\color{#D61F06}{10}^{\\color{#3D99F6}{20}}-\\color{#624F41}2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^20-2 this means "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
10000...(20 times 0) "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
subtract 1 means 20 times 9 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
subtract 2 means 19 times 9 and then 8 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
i.e, 19X9+8 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
171+8 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
179"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            When you subract 1 from 10^20 you would have have a total of 19 digits. Out of those 19, 18 are the digit 9 and one is 8. So the total should be 18*9+8=170

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^20 has 21 digits out of which 20 are 0s and one 1. So subtracting 2 from it yeilds a 20 digit no. of which there are nineteen 9s and one 8.
Sum =  19*9 + 8 = 179"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: (10) - Outcoming
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\text{E}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the midpoint of line segment "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\text{DA}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of trapezium (trapezoid) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\text{ABCD}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\text{BC} \\parallel \\text{DA}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\text{AB} = \\text{CD}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\widehat{\\text{CAB}} = \\widehat{\\text{BCD}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\widehat{\\text{ECD}} = \\widehat{\\text{DBC}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Calculate the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\left(\\dfrac{\\text{EC} \\cdot \\widehat{\\text{CDA}}}{\\text{BD} \\cdot \\widehat{\\text{BCD}}}\\right)^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            A percentage isn't a variable you can assign a value to, rather it is a fraction out of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". e.g. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"52"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"% "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= \frac{52}{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To take your example. If we had "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"300"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" apples, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"% would be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"30"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" apples but "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"% "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"* 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"% would be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" apples."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To further explain this, the percentage sign is used to denote a fraction of a number ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"% "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= \frac{10}{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for example). Every percentage in an equation must first be simplified down to one percentage in order to properly calculate the result."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In the form of a general equation:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"% "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"* b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"% of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= \frac{ab}{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"% of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            If I have 300 apples
10%=30 apples
10% * 10% = 30 apples  * 30 apples = 900 apples  = 300%

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 101010 points
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/gHIQhiBcgJ-aaa.png?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In a field there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" points. Each point is connected to another point with a line. If no "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" points are collinear, how many possible number of triangles can we construct using the 3 dots as its vertices?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given 10 dots. Each triangle has 3 vertices. So the number of possible triangles is"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{ C }_{ 3 }^{ 10 }=\frac { 10! }{ 3!7! } =\frac { 10\cdot 9\cdot 8 }{ 3\cdot 2\cdot 1 } =120"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 10 Questions packed into one Question
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For statements that is correct, type 1. For statements that is incorrect, type 2. For statements that is partially correct, type 3. So the answer is a 10-digit number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
1) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt [ 3 ]{ 27 } \quad -\quad \sqrt { 9 } \quad =\quad 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
2) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\log { 10 } \quad \times \quad \log { 100 } \quad =\quad \log { 1000 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
3) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{ x }^{ 2 }\quad -\quad 2x\quad -\quad 3\quad =\quad 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has the factors "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x\quad =\quad -1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x\quad =\quad 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
4) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{ 999 }^{ 999 }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divisible by 3 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
5) Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has 2 trailing zeros, and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has 4 trailing zeros, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10! + 20!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has 6 trailing zeros "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
6) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"sin\quad { 2460 }^{ \circ  }\quad =\quad sin\quad { 300 }^{ \circ  }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
7) If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f\left( x \right) \quad =\quad \frac { ax\quad +\quad b }{ cx\quad +\quad d } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f^{ -1 }\left( x \right) \quad =\quad \frac { -dx\quad +\quad b }{ cx\quad -\quad a } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
8) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt [ 4 ]{ x } \quad \times \quad \sqrt [ 4 ]{ x } \quad =\quad \sqrt { x } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
9) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lim _{ n\quad \rightarrow \quad 1 }{ \frac { { n }^{ 2 }\quad -\quad 1 }{ n\quad -\quad 1 }  } \quad =\quad 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
10) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac { \sqrt [ 10 ]{ 10 }  }{ \log _{ 10 }{ 10 }  } \quad =\quad \frac { 5 }{ 2 } \pi "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}
